The **Knight**, abbreviated as **Kni**, is one of the [roles](/wiki/Role "Role") available for a [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The [guidebook](/wiki/Guidebook "Guidebook") has relatively little to say about Knights:

Knights are distinguished from the common skirmisher by their devotion to the ideals of chivalry and by the surpassing excellence of their armor.

Knights are always [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") [humans](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)").

## Starting equipment

Each Knight starts with the following equipment:[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

- a +1 [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword") ([wielded](/wiki/Wielded "Wielded"))
- a +1 [lance](/wiki/Lance "Lance") (alternate weapon)
- a +1 [ring mail](/wiki/Ring_mail "Ring mail")
- a +0 [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet")
- a +0 [small shield](/wiki/Small_shield "Small shield")
- a +0 pair of [leather gloves](/wiki/Leather_gloves "Leather gloves")
- 10-20 uncursed [apples](/wiki/Apple "Apple")
- 10-20 uncursed [carrots](/wiki/Carrot "Carrot")

Knights start with knowledge of all non-[magical](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item") weapons and armor.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

The Knight's default starting pet is a [saddled](/wiki/Saddled "Saddled") [pony](/wiki/Pony "Pony").

## Intrinsics

Knights gain the following intrinsic [properties](/wiki/Properties "Properties") upon reaching the given [experience levels](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level"):[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

- Level 7: [Speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed")

Knights start with *Basic* skill in *longsword*, *lance*, and *riding*.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6) They use the wisdom stat to cast spells, and their special spell is [turn undead](/wiki/Spellbook_of_turn_undead "Spellbook of turn undead").[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

## Special rules

Knights have an inherent ability to [jump](/wiki/Jump "Jump") like [the knight piece in chess](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knight_\(chess\) "wikipedia:Knight (chess)") - this ability is restricted to destinations two squares horizontally and one square vertically away, or vice versa. Jumping from other sources (i.e. [jumping boots](/wiki/Jumping_boots "Jumping boots") or the [jumping](/wiki/Spellbook_of_jumping "Spellbook of jumping") spell) function as normal.

Knights can [turn undead](/wiki/Turn_undead "Turn undead") via the [turn](/wiki/Turn_\(command\) "Turn (command)") [command](/wiki/Command "Command").

Knights do not reduce the [tameness](/wiki/Tameness "Tameness") of a steed when mounting it.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Knights ignore penalties for metal body armor while casting [clerical spells](/wiki/Clerical_spells "Clerical spells"), which is adapted from [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack").

Knights are the only role to retain a 1⁄6 chance of creating [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") by [dipping](/wiki/Dipping "Dipping") a long sword in a [fountain](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain").

### Knightly conduct

Knights follow a code of conduct, and take a -1 penalty to [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record") for the following actions withe the accompanying messages being printed:

- Attacking a [sleeping](/wiki/Sleeping "Sleeping"), [paralyzed](/wiki/Paralyzed "Paralyzed") or [fleeing](/wiki/Fleeing "Fleeing") monster in melee, even if the monster continues to attack while fleeing - this does not apply to monsters that flee after stealing items from the hero. Monsters putting on armor or items (e.g., "the soldier puts on a crested helmet") are considered paralyzed for this purpose. Projectiles, wands and spells do not incur a penalty.

* You caitiff!

- [Eating](/wiki/Eating "Eating") while [satiated](/wiki/Satiated "Satiated").

* You feel like a glutton!

- [Digging](/wiki/Digging "Digging") down in a [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop"), if the [shopkeeper](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") is alive.

* You feel like a common thief.

## Rank titles

The [status line](/wiki/Status_line "Status line") displays one of the following ranks for the corresponding experience levels:[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)

- XL 1–2: Gallant
- XL 3–5: Esquire
- XL 6–9: Bachelor
- XL 10–13: Sergeant
- XL 14–17: Knight
- XL 18–21: Banneret
- XL 22–25: Chevalier/Chevaliere
- XL 26–29: Seignieur/Dame
- XL 30: Paladin

## Gods

- *Main article: [Religion](/wiki/Religion "Religion")*

The Knight pantheon is based on [the mythology of Celtic peoples](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celtic_mythology "wikipedia:Celtic mythology").[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

- Lawful: [Lugh](/wiki/Lugh "Lugh")
- Neutral: [Brigit](/wiki/Brigit "Brigit")
- Chaotic: [Manannan Mac Lir](/wiki/Manannan_Mac_Lir "Manannan Mac Lir")

## Quest

- *Main article: [Knight quest](/wiki/Knight_quest "Knight quest")*

The Knight's quest them fighting [Ixoth](/wiki/Ixoth "Ixoth") for [The Magic Mirror of Merlin](/wiki/The_Magic_Mirror_of_Merlin "The Magic Mirror of Merlin"), an artifact [mirror](/wiki/Mirror "Mirror"). It grants [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") and [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy") while carried, and a Knight carrying it also deals doubled damage to their enemies with offensive magic (i.e. some wands and most spells). [Applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") or [wielding](/wiki/Wield "Wield") the Mirror causes it to speak a random rumor that is true if the Mirror is blessed, false if cursed and either if uncursed.

## Strategy

In terms of [role difficulty](/wiki/Role_difficulty "Role difficulty"), Knights are a relatively balanced role, if somewhat more difficult than average: their stats lean towards higher strength, and their enchanted long sword is easily one of the best melee weapons to start a game with even before considering the ease of access to [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur"). Their affinity for mounted combat also lets them get more out of polearms and their starting lance - said lance is also quite heavy, to the point that many players will drop or stash it at the first opportunity. Conversely, maximizing [luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck") and then mastering combat with lances as soon as possible can give Knights a significant edge over otherwise-difficult monsters in combat, up to and including their [quest nemesis](/wiki/Quest_nemesis "Quest nemesis").

### Early game

The Knight's special jump can be a handy escape tool early in the game, providing an extra opportunity to engrave [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") or escape to a [stairway](/wiki/Stairway "Stairway"), though it does cost [nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition") for each jump. Between this and the lack of food outside of the fruits and vegetables intended for the starting pony, the hero's first priority should be stocking up on permafood in general. The starting [pony](/wiki/Pony "Pony") is likely your best asset for getting around quickly: it is a strong and fast pet and can finish off fleeing monsters in order to avoid early [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record") penalties.

A natural early game goal for a Knight is to transform their +1 long sword into Excalibur once they hit [experience level](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") 5 - more cautious Knights may choose to wait until they train up their [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") and [constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") and/or gain intrinsic speed at XL 7. The starting pony can also provide enough speed to make an escape if necessary, especially if they are given intrinsic speed of their own (e.g. via [wand of speed monster](/wiki/Wand_of_speed_monster "Wand of speed monster")), or else they [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into a [horse](/wiki/Horse "Horse") or [warhorse](/wiki/Warhorse "Warhorse") - see the dedicated section about [steeds](#Your_steed) for more information.

Attacking from range with the lance works as with [polearms](/wiki/Polearms "Polearms"), requiring that the hero be able to see the target square - see the article on [pounding](/wiki/Pounding "Pounding") for details. Attacking with the lance in melee can joust opponents, stunning them and pushing them one square away (which is the perfect range for another round of pounding), but a starting Knight will rarely succeed in jousting, and runs a low-but-notable risk of breaking the lance at a stage when it is hard to replace. Additionally, Knights do not start with high STR and CON as consistently as other roles like the [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai") and [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie"), and can easily become [encumbered](/wiki/Encumbered "Encumbered") early on: as discussed above, [stashing](/wiki/Stash "Stash") the starting lance may be a good idea, especially if you find more reliable and lightweight [ranged attack](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack") options.

The Knight starts with a relatively full set of armor that grants them the best starting [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") of all roles at 3, notably including [leather gloves](/wiki/Leather_gloves "Leather gloves"): while finding lighter and better-quality armor, Knights should seek out a [cloak](/wiki/Cloak "Cloak") to protect their body armor from rusting, as well as a set of [boots](/wiki/Boots "Boots"). Plumbing the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines") for a [dwarvish mithril-coat](/wiki/Dwarvish_mithril-coat "Dwarvish mithril-coat"), [iron shoes](/wiki/Iron_shoes "Iron shoes") and/or [dwarvish iron helm](/wiki/Dwarvish_iron_helm "Dwarvish iron helm") is risky - unlit levels rob Knights of most of their mobility and combat advantages; as they are always human and lack [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"), a Knight will want a [light source](/wiki/Light_source "Light source") as soon as possible if they plan to brave the Mines.

Knights looking to start casting early will have to play more carefully than usual: their starting [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") is typically low, making it dangerous to read non-blessed [spellbooks](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook"), and their metallic armor makes casting itself difficult. Outside of an early wish for [silver dragon scale mail](/wiki/Silver_dragon_scale_mail "Silver dragon scale mail"), the next best option is [crystal plate mail](/wiki/Crystal_plate_mail "Crystal plate mail"), which is both rare and incredibly heavy - [studded leather armor](/wiki/Studded_leather_armor "Studded leather armor") is the most practical spellcasting-friendly armor, and has the same base AC as [ring mail](/wiki/Ring_mail "Ring mail").

### Your steed

- -
  - *Main articles: [Riding](/wiki/Riding "Riding") and [Saddle](/wiki/Saddle "Saddle")*

For Knights planning to make extensive use of their steed, be sure to bless the [saddle](/wiki/Saddle "Saddle") as soon as possible with spare potions of holy water. At minimum, raising the starting pony into a 20-base speed horse is worthwhile, as riding sets the hero's movement speed to that of their mount - remember that all horses are [vegetarian](/wiki/Vegetarian "Vegetarian"), and gain more nutrition from veggy food such as the starting apples and oranges unless they are starving.[\[10\]](#cite_note-dog_nutrition-10)[\[11\]](#cite_note-starving_dog-11) A horse close to starvation will also accept "people food" such as [food rations](/wiki/Food_ration "Food ration"), or even meat in a pinch - remember to heal them as soon as possible afterward, since starving pets have their maximum HP cut to 1⁄3 of their normal value.[\[12\]](#cite_note-notstarving-12)[\[13\]](#cite_note-mhpmax_penalty-13)

As a result, while a Knight will not potentially have to compete with their starting pet for food like many other roles, finding suitable food for a pony can be generally more difficult: #[chat](/wiki/Chat "Chat") to a steed regularly (using [>](/wiki/Angle_bracket "Angle bracket") if riding it) in order to monitor its status. Carefully rationing the starting food is vital to maintaining the starting steed's health in the long term, and a horse will also gladly feed on the corpses of [lichens](/wiki/Lichen "Lichen") and [red](/wiki/Red_mold "Red mold") or [brown molds](/wiki/Brown_mold "Brown mold"). One good early strategy is to feed the starting pony 9 apples as soon as it drops an item: this increases its tameness enough that a Knight can reliably mount it without slipping - which deals 10-14 damage and [may spell doom](/wiki/YASD "YASD") for a starting Knight (sometimes even [instantly!](/wiki/Do_not_pass_go._Do_not_collect_200_zorkmids. "Do not pass go. Do not collect 200 zorkmids.")) - as well as increasing its [apport](/wiki/Apport "Apport") for liberating items from shops.

Another strategy is to avoid mounting the pony until it has gained enough HP, usually enough to become a horse: by that point, the hero will likely have gained a few levels as well. Steeds in general will not attack monsters as often while the hero is mounted, and will only counterattack if a monster attack targeting you falls upon them instead - it is sometimes best to dismount and let them handle weaker monsters, such as the aforementioned [fungi and molds](/wiki/Fungus_or_mold "Fungus or mold"). For a hero short on food in general, one unorthodox method is to leave a level just before the horse becomes confused from hunger, let it go feral, and then return with food after the point where it would have starved if you had remained on the level; taming a monster always sets its hunger level to satiated.

Unknown [rings](/wiki/Ring "Ring") present a greater danger than normal for aspiring riders: putting on an unknown [ring of conflict](/wiki/Ring_of_conflict "Ring of conflict") will cause the steed to buck its rider off immediately, resulting in [wounded legs](/wiki/Wounded_legs "Wounded legs") and a possible severe beating before the hero can get their next turn! Additionally, when descending past [Mine Town](/wiki/Mine_Town "Mine Town") or below DL 7, be especially careful of [polymorph traps](/wiki/Polymorph_traps "Polymorph traps"): [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") will protect both the hero and steed from transformation.

### Mid game

Once decently enchanted, Excalibur is more than sufficient to carry most Knights throughout the entire game. Some Knights may also decide to joust long-term after gaining sufficient skill and [luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck"), obtaining a [luckstone](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone") if they haven't already, and may even [twoweapon](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon") their lance in the offhand with Excalibur. Improving [carrying capacity](/wiki/Carrying_capacity "Carrying capacity") is also highly recommended due to the lance's weight. Alignment record is easily recovered by this point, so violations of conduct are often considered an annoyance at worst; taking fewer penalties (or even none) is still ideal, but there is much more room for error.

The stunning from a just can keep monsters off-balance as well, usually knocking them into pounding range; [invisibility](/wiki/Invisibility "Invisibility") or displacement can aid in keeping hostile monsters wandering aimlessly and staying (or straying) into range of further pounds. Even once they have secured enough luck, a Knight will likely want to reserve their lance for stronger opponents in order to further minimize the odds of it breaking, using their primary weapon to handle weaker hostiles. [Soldiers](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") are sometimes generated with lances, making [barracks](/wiki/Barracks "Barracks") such as those in [Fort Ludios](/wiki/Fort_Ludios "Fort Ludios") and the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") good places to look for a replacement or spare lance.

Whether or not the hero commits to using a lance or even riding a steed, stashing any treasure and other excess items is an especially good idea for Knights in particular: maximizing speed is extremely important for combat from this point forward, both to keep jumping available as an option and to either evade foes or run them down before they can deal too much damage. A [bag of holding](/wiki/Bag_of_holding "Bag of holding") can easily do most of the work in that regard. If you opt to press on while encumbered, be prepared to shed excess items (e.g. stashing them in a [sack](/wiki/Sack "Sack") that can be dropped at a moment's notice) when dealing with particularly troublesome enemies. The quest nemesis [Ixoth](/wiki/Ixoth "Ixoth") is easily among the tougher hostiles a Knight will face inin general —although he can be dealt with using [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") or paralysis, his [spellcasting](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") ability is annoying to handle without magic resistance, and may warrant heading to the Castle first.

For dedicated Knight riders, [black dragons](/wiki/Black_dragon "Black dragon") are likely the worst threat they can encounter - even if a hero can [resist](/wiki/Disintegration_resistance "Disintegration resistance") or [reflect](/wiki/Reflect "Reflect") their [disintegration](/wiki/Disintegration "Disintegration") [breath](/wiki/Breath "Breath") weapons, the vast majority of mounts cannot, and losing a steed to disintegration usually means losing the saddle as well. One of the better tactics to avoid this is to have a means of detecting the dragon beforehand (e.g. via [Dragonbane](/wiki/Dragonbane "Dragonbane") or [monster detection](/wiki/Monster_detection "Monster detection")), use your mount's speed to close in while avoiding their line of fire, and then defeat them in melee by jousting, using Excalibur or any other main weapon of choice. This can also be used to deal with Ixoth by drawing him to your position (typically via the standard cursed [potion of invisibility](/wiki/Potion_of_invisibility "Potion of invisibility")) and then repeatedly jousting him, which is most effective on a warhorse or faster steed with Expert in lances.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

### Late game

There are many routes for offense that a late game Knight can take, some of which overlap with enough savvy or foresight:

- Excalibur remains a stellar weapon as ever, only potentially being outperformed by [Frost Brand](/wiki/Frost_Brand "Frost Brand") and [Grayswandir](/wiki/Grayswandir "Grayswandir"), and as mentioned earlier can be twoweaponed with weapons such as a lance, a [silver saber](/wiki/Silver_saber "Silver saber") or a [silver spear](/wiki/Silver_spear "Silver spear"). Knights planning to bribe their way past [Asmodeus](/wiki/Asmodeus "Asmodeus") and/or [Baalzebub](/wiki/Baalzebub "Baalzebub") should unwield them before potentially entering their lairs - a demon prince that is generated or warps to demand a bribe while the hero wields Excalibur will immediately turn hostile.
- Knights with Expert in lances and a very fast mount can deal severe damage to monsters such as minotaurs, dragons and high-level demons through jousting and pounding, potentially without losing a single hit point.
- Knights seeking to maintain steeds throughout the entire game will find [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") to be the most difficult challenge in that regard. [Ki-rin](/wiki/Ki-rin "Ki-rin") are among the most likely to last through Gehennom, and may perhaps be the only ones that can survive the branch consistently: they do not require feeding, have stellar AC, can haste and heal themselves, and Knights will not lower their tameness by mounting one. Unfortunately, they are very hard to obtain, with the best chance being a [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for a blessed [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") that has an 80% chance of generating a tamed ki-rin - they are also not immune to [death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death") and disintegration rays, and their lack of poison resistance will likely spell their doom on the [Plane of Fire](/wiki/Plane_of_Fire "Plane of Fire") unless the hero can avoid the [poison cloud](/wiki/Poison_cloud "Poison cloud") plumes.
- Knights that begin investing in spellcasting in the mid-game can amass a formidable array of spells, and their high wisdom naturally lends itself to a large [energy](/wiki/Energy "Energy") pool. The Magic Mirror allows a knight with a well-trained [magic missile](/wiki/Spellbook_of_magic_missile "Spellbook of magic missile") However, their energy regeneration is as slow as anyone else's, and one of the best ways to reasonably alleviate this is [The Mitre of Holiness](/wiki/The_Mitre_of_Holiness "The Mitre of Holiness"), which requires an artifact wish - spellcasting Knights should conserve their spells for the moments when they are most effective. Additionally, the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") can steal the Mirror and gain magic resistance, so stashing it may usually be the safer option.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Ki-rins have poison resistance, and are no longer considered [animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal")—they can also cure their status ailments using their horns, similar to [unicorns](/wiki/Unicorn "Unicorn") and their [horns](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn").

## History

The Knight first appears in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0")

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Knight](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knight "wikipedia:Knight")***

The Knight as a role is based on historical and fictional stereotypes of medieval knights.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

- *Main article: [Knight/SLASH'EM](/wiki/Knight/SLASH%27EM "Knight/SLASH'EM")*

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), Knights start out with [plate mail](/wiki/Plate_mail "Plate mail") and a [large shield](/wiki/Large_shield "Large shield") among their armor, which is far heavier but also ensures much better starting AC and carrying capacity; this simplifies the search for better armor such as the various mithril-coats, and can consistently produce a starting strength of at least 18 for valuable early damage bonuses - while their constitution is similarly rarely lower than 12, their HP growth is still somewhat lackluster. Knights retain their starting long sword and ease of access to Excalibur, and the starting steed is also easier to keep fed using the fungi and molds that grow from old corpses.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), a Knight can also be a lawful [dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)"). Knights wearing any body armor heavier than [studded leather armor](/wiki/Studded_leather_armor "Studded leather armor") receive a weight reduction for it equal to half the difference;[\[14\]](#cite_note-14) this allows them to carry more while wearing heavy armor before becoming burdened.

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), Knights can be dwarves as well as humans. Knights are always warned before violating their honor code, and [Dragonbane](/wiki/Dragonbane "Dragonbane") is the guaranteed first sacrifice gift for them.

## Encyclopedia entry

Here lies the noble fearless knight,  
Whose valour rose to such a height;  
When Death at last had struck him down,  
His was the victory and renown.  
He reck'd the world of little prize,

The Knight, abbreviated as Kni, is one of the roles available for a hero in NetHack. The guidebook has relatively little to say about Knights:

Knights are distinguished from the common skirmisher by their devotion to the ideals of chivalry and by the surpassing excellence of their armor.

Knights are always lawful humans.

Starting equipment

Each Knight starts with the following equipment:[1]

  • a +1 long sword (wielded)
  • a +1 lance (alternate weapon)
  • a +1 ring mail
  • a +0 helmet
  • a +0 small shield
  • a +0 pair of leather gloves
  • 10-20 uncursed apples
  • 10-20 uncursed carrots

Knights start with knowledge of all non-magical weapons and armor.[2]

The Knight's default starting pet is a saddled pony.

Intrinsics

Knights gain the following intrinsic properties upon reaching the given experience levels:[3]

  • Level 7: Speed

Attributes

The Knight's starting attributes are distributed as follows:[4]

Attributes Strength Dexterity Constitution Intelligence Wisdom Charisma Remaining
Minimum attributes 13 8 10 7 14 17 6
Distribution percentages 30% 10% 20% 15% 15% 10%
Mean w/ standard deviation 14.95±1.24 8.66±0.89 11.27±1.10 7.97±1.01 14.96±0.97 17.43±0.53

Skills

Knights have the following skills available to them:[5]

Knight skills
Max Skills
Basic
  • Weapons: dagger, knife, pick-axe, scimitar, club, flail, hammer, trident, bow
Skilled
  • Weapons: axe, short sword, broadsword, two-handed sword, saber, mace, morning star, polearms, spear, crossbow
  • Combat: two weapon combat
  • Spells: attack, healing, clerical
Expert
  • Weapons: long sword, lance
  • Combat: bare hands, riding

Knights start with Basic skill in longsword, lance, and riding.[6] They use the wisdom stat to cast spells, and their special spell is turn undead.[7]

Special rules

Knights have an inherent ability to jump like the knight piece in chess - this ability is restricted to destinations two squares horizontally and one square vertically away, or vice versa. Jumping from other sources (i.e. jumping boots or the jumping spell) function as normal.

Knights can turn undead via the turn command.

Knights do not reduce the tameness of a steed when mounting it.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Knights ignore penalties for metal body armor while casting clerical spells, which is adapted from SporkHack.

Knights are the only role to retain a 1⁄6 chance of creating Excalibur by dipping a long sword in a fountain.

Knightly conduct

Knights follow a code of conduct, and take a -1 penalty to alignment record for the following actions withe the accompanying messages being printed:

  • Attacking a sleeping, paralyzed or fleeing monster in melee, even if the monster continues to attack while fleeing - this does not apply to monsters that flee after stealing items from the hero. Monsters putting on armor or items (e.g., "the soldier puts on a crested helmet") are considered paralyzed for this purpose. Projectiles, wands and spells do not incur a penalty.
You caitiff!
  • Eating while satiated.
You feel like a glutton!
  • Digging down in a shop, if the shopkeeper is alive.
You feel like a common thief.

Rank titles

The status line displays one of the following ranks for the corresponding experience levels:[8]

  • XL 1–2: Gallant
  • XL 3–5: Esquire
  • XL 6–9: Bachelor
  • XL 10–13: Sergeant
  • XL 14–17: Knight
  • XL 18–21: Banneret
  • XL 22–25: Chevalier/Chevaliere
  • XL 26–29: Seignieur/Dame
  • XL 30: Paladin

Gods

Main article: Religion

The Knight pantheon is based on the mythology of Celtic peoples.[9]

  • Lawful: Lugh
  • Neutral: Brigit
  • Chaotic: Manannan Mac Lir

Quest

Main article: Knight quest

The Knight's quest them fighting Ixoth for The Magic Mirror of Merlin, an artifact mirror. It grants magic resistance and telepathy while carried, and a Knight carrying it also deals doubled damage to their enemies with offensive magic (i.e. some wands and most spells). Applying or wielding the Mirror causes it to speak a random rumor that is true if the Mirror is blessed, false if cursed and either if uncursed.

Strategy

In terms of role difficulty, Knights are a relatively balanced role, if somewhat more difficult than average: their stats lean towards higher strength, and their enchanted long sword is easily one of the best melee weapons to start a game with even before considering the ease of access to Excalibur. Their affinity for mounted combat also lets them get more out of polearms and their starting lance - said lance is also quite heavy, to the point that many players will drop or stash it at the first opportunity. Conversely, maximizing luck and then mastering combat with lances as soon as possible can give Knights a significant edge over otherwise-difficult monsters in combat, up to and including their quest nemesis.

Early game

The Knight's special jump can be a handy escape tool early in the game, providing an extra opportunity to engrave Elbereth or escape to a stairway, though it does cost nutrition for each jump. Between this and the lack of food outside of the fruits and vegetables intended for the starting pony, the hero's first priority should be stocking up on permafood in general. The starting pony is likely your best asset for getting around quickly: it is a strong and fast pet and can finish off fleeing monsters in order to avoid early alignment record penalties.

A natural early game goal for a Knight is to transform their +1 long sword into Excalibur once they hit experience level 5 - more cautious Knights may choose to wait until they train up their strength and constitution and/or gain intrinsic speed at XL 7. The starting pony can also provide enough speed to make an escape if necessary, especially if they are given intrinsic speed of their own (e.g. via wand of speed monster), or else they grow up into a horse or warhorse - see the dedicated section about steeds for more information.

Attacking from range with the lance works as with polearms, requiring that the hero be able to see the target square - see the article on pounding for details. Attacking with the lance in melee can joust opponents, stunning them and pushing them one square away (which is the perfect range for another round of pounding), but a starting Knight will rarely succeed in jousting, and runs a low-but-notable risk of breaking the lance at a stage when it is hard to replace. Additionally, Knights do not start with high STR and CON as consistently as other roles like the Samurai and Valkyrie, and can easily become encumbered early on: as discussed above, stashing the starting lance may be a good idea, especially if you find more reliable and lightweight ranged attack options.

The Knight starts with a relatively full set of armor that grants them the best starting AC of all roles at 3, notably including leather gloves: while finding lighter and better-quality armor, Knights should seek out a cloak to protect their body armor from rusting, as well as a set of boots. Plumbing the Gnomish Mines for a dwarvish mithril-coat, iron shoes and/or dwarvish iron helm is risky - unlit levels rob Knights of most of their mobility and combat advantages; as they are always human and lack infravision, a Knight will want a light source as soon as possible if they plan to brave the Mines.

Knights looking to start casting early will have to play more carefully than usual: their starting intelligence is typically low, making it dangerous to read non-blessed spellbooks, and their metallic armor makes casting itself difficult. Outside of an early wish for silver dragon scale mail, the next best option is crystal plate mail, which is both rare and incredibly heavy - studded leather armor is the most practical spellcasting-friendly armor, and has the same base AC as ring mail.

Your steed

Main articles: Riding and Saddle

For Knights planning to make extensive use of their steed, be sure to bless the saddle as soon as possible with spare potions of holy water. At minimum, raising the starting pony into a 20-base speed horse is worthwhile, as riding sets the hero's movement speed to that of their mount - remember that all horses are vegetarian, and gain more nutrition from veggy food such as the starting apples and oranges unless they are starving.[10][11] A horse close to starvation will also accept "people food" such as food rations, or even meat in a pinch - remember to heal them as soon as possible afterward, since starving pets have their maximum HP cut to 1⁄3 of their normal value.[12][13]

As a result, while a Knight will not potentially have to compete with their starting pet for food like many other roles, finding suitable food for a pony can be generally more difficult: #chat to a steed regularly (using > if riding it) in order to monitor its status. Carefully rationing the starting food is vital to maintaining the starting steed's health in the long term, and a horse will also gladly feed on the corpses of lichens and red or brown molds. One good early strategy is to feed the starting pony 9 apples as soon as it drops an item: this increases its tameness enough that a Knight can reliably mount it without slipping - which deals 10-14 damage and may spell doom for a starting Knight (sometimes even instantly!) - as well as increasing its apport for liberating items from shops.

Another strategy is to avoid mounting the pony until it has gained enough HP, usually enough to become a horse: by that point, the hero will likely have gained a few levels as well. Steeds in general will not attack monsters as often while the hero is mounted, and will only counterattack if a monster attack targeting you falls upon them instead - it is sometimes best to dismount and let them handle weaker monsters, such as the aforementioned fungi and molds. For a hero short on food in general, one unorthodox method is to leave a level just before the horse becomes confused from hunger, let it go feral, and then return with food after the point where it would have starved if you had remained on the level; taming a monster always sets its hunger level to satiated.

Unknown rings present a greater danger than normal for aspiring riders: putting on an unknown ring of conflict will cause the steed to buck its rider off immediately, resulting in wounded legs and a possible severe beating before the hero can get their next turn! Additionally, when descending past Mine Town or below DL 7, be especially careful of polymorph traps: magic resistance will protect both the hero and steed from transformation.

Mid game

Once decently enchanted, Excalibur is more than sufficient to carry most Knights throughout the entire game. Some Knights may also decide to joust long-term after gaining sufficient skill and luck, obtaining a luckstone if they haven't already, and may even twoweapon their lance in the offhand with Excalibur. Improving carrying capacity is also highly recommended due to the lance's weight. Alignment record is easily recovered by this point, so violations of conduct are often considered an annoyance at worst; taking fewer penalties (or even none) is still ideal, but there is much more room for error.

The stunning from a just can keep monsters off-balance as well, usually knocking them into pounding range; invisibility or displacement can aid in keeping hostile monsters wandering aimlessly and staying (or straying) into range of further pounds. Even once they have secured enough luck, a Knight will likely want to reserve their lance for stronger opponents in order to further minimize the odds of it breaking, using their primary weapon to handle weaker hostiles. Soldiers are sometimes generated with lances, making barracks such as those in Fort Ludios and the Castle good places to look for a replacement or spare lance.

Whether or not the hero commits to using a lance or even riding a steed, stashing any treasure and other excess items is an especially good idea for Knights in particular: maximizing speed is extremely important for combat from this point forward, both to keep jumping available as an option and to either evade foes or run them down before they can deal too much damage. A bag of holding can easily do most of the work in that regard. If you opt to press on while encumbered, be prepared to shed excess items (e.g. stashing them in a sack that can be dropped at a moment's notice) when dealing with particularly troublesome enemies. The quest nemesis Ixoth is easily among the tougher hostiles a Knight will face inin general —although he can be dealt with using Elbereth or paralysis, his spellcasting ability is annoying to handle without magic resistance, and may warrant heading to the Castle first.

For dedicated Knight riders, black dragons are likely the worst threat they can encounter - even if a hero can resist or reflect their disintegration breath weapons, the vast majority of mounts cannot, and losing a steed to disintegration usually means losing the saddle as well. One of the better tactics to avoid this is to have a means of detecting the dragon beforehand (e.g. via Dragonbane or monster detection), use your mount's speed to close in while avoiding their line of fire, and then defeat them in melee by jousting, using Excalibur or any other main weapon of choice. This can also be used to deal with Ixoth by drawing him to your position (typically via the standard cursed potion of invisibility) and then repeatedly jousting him, which is most effective on a warhorse or faster steed with Expert in lances.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

"Mention spellcasting in some capacity."

Late game

There are many routes for offense that a late game Knight can take, some of which overlap with enough savvy or foresight:

  • Excalibur remains a stellar weapon as ever, only potentially being outperformed by Frost Brand and Grayswandir, and as mentioned earlier can be twoweaponed with weapons such as a lance, a silver saber or a silver spear. Knights planning to bribe their way past Asmodeus and/or Baalzebub should unwield them before potentially entering their lairs - a demon prince that is generated or warps to demand a bribe while the hero wields Excalibur will immediately turn hostile.
  • Knights with Expert in lances and a very fast mount can deal severe damage to monsters such as minotaurs, dragons and high-level demons through jousting and pounding, potentially without losing a single hit point.
  • Knights seeking to maintain steeds throughout the entire game will find Gehennom to be the most difficult challenge in that regard. Ki-rin are among the most likely to last through Gehennom, and may perhaps be the only ones that can survive the branch consistently: they do not require feeding, have stellar AC, can haste and heal themselves, and Knights will not lower their tameness by mounting one. Unfortunately, they are very hard to obtain, with the best chance being a wish for a blessed figurine that has an 80% chance of generating a tamed ki-rin - they are also not immune to death and disintegration rays, and their lack of poison resistance will likely spell their doom on the Plane of Fire unless the hero can avoid the poison cloud plumes.
  • Knights that begin investing in spellcasting in the mid-game can amass a formidable array of spells, and their high wisdom naturally lends itself to a large energy pool. The Magic Mirror allows a knight with a well-trained magic missile However, their energy regeneration is as slow as anyone else's, and one of the best ways to reasonably alleviate this is The Mitre of Holiness, which requires an artifact wish - spellcasting Knights should conserve their spells for the moments when they are most effective. Additionally, the Wizard of Yendor can steal the Mirror and gain magic resistance, so stashing it may usually be the safer option.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Ki-rins have poison resistance, and are no longer considered animals—they can also cure their status ailments using their horns, similar to unicorns and their horns.

History

The Knight first appears in Hack 1.0

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Knight

The Knight as a role is based on historical and fictional stereotypes of medieval knights.

Variants

SLASH'EM

Main article: Knight/SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, Knights start out with plate mail and a large shield among their armor, which is far heavier but also ensures much better starting AC and carrying capacity; this simplifies the search for better armor such as the various mithril-coats, and can consistently produce a starting strength of at least 18 for valuable early damage bonuses - while their constitution is similarly rarely lower than 12, their HP growth is still somewhat lackluster. Knights retain their starting long sword and ease of access to Excalibur, and the starting steed is also easier to keep fed using the fungi and molds that grow from old corpses.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, a Knight can also be a lawful dwarf. Knights wearing any body armor heavier than studded leather armor receive a weight reduction for it equal to half the difference;[14] this allows them to carry more while wearing heavy armor before becoming burdened.

FIQHack

In FIQHack, Knights can be dwarves as well as humans. Knights are always warned before violating their honor code, and Dragonbane is the guaranteed first sacrifice gift for them.

Encyclopedia entry

Here lies the noble fearless knight,
Whose valour rose to such a height;
When Death at last had struck him down,
His was the victory and renown.
He reck'd the world of little prize,
And was a bugbear in men's eyes;
But had the fortune in his age
To live a fool and die a sage.

[ Don Quixote of La Mancha by Miquel de Cervantes Saavedra ]

[[Apply]]ing or [[wield]]ing the Mirror causes it to speak a random rumor that is true if the Mirror is blessed, false if cursed and either if uncursed.

==Strategy==
In terms of [[role difficulty]], Knights are a relatively balanced role, if somewhat more difficult than average: their stats lean towards higher strength, and their enchanted long sword is easily one of the best melee weapons to start a game with even before considering the ease of access to [[Excalibur]]. Their affinity for mounted combat also lets them get more out of polearms and their starting lance - said lance is also quite heavy, to the point that many players will drop or stash it at the first opportunity. Conversely, maximizing [[luck]] and then mastering combat with lances as soon as possible can give Knights a significant edge over otherwise-difficult monsters in combat, up to and including their [[quest nemesis]].

===Early game===
The Knight's special jump can be a handy escape tool early in the game, providing an extra opportunity to engrave [[Elbereth]] or escape to a [[stairway]], though it does cost [[nutrition]] for each jump. Between this and the lack of food outside of the fruits and vegetables intended for the starting pony, the hero's first priority should be stocking up on permafood in general. The starting [[pony]] is likely your best asset for getting around quickly: it is a strong and fast pet and can finish off fleeing monsters in order to avoid early [[alignment record]] penalties.

A natural early game goal for a Knight is to transform their +1 long sword into Excalibur once they hit [[experience level]] 5 - more cautious Knights may choose to wait until they train up their [[strength]] and [[constitution]] and/or gain intrinsic speed at XL 7. The starting pony can also provide enough speed to make an escape if necessary, especially if they are given intrinsic speed of their own (e.g. via [[wand of speed monster]]), or else they [[grow up]] into a [[horse]] or [[warhorse]] - see the dedicated section about {{sa|Your steed|steeds}} for more information.

Attacking from range with the lance works as with [[polearms]], requiring that the hero be able to see the target square - see the article on [[pounding]] for details. Attacking with the lance in melee can joust opponents, stunning them and pushing them one square away (which is the perfect range for another round of pounding), but a starting Knight will rarely succeed in jousting, and runs a low-but-notable risk of breaking the lance at a stage when it is hard to replace. Additionally, Knights do not start with high STR and CON as consistently as other roles like the [[Samurai]] and [[Valkyrie]], and can easily become [[encumbered]] early on: as discussed above, [[stash]]ing the starting lance may be a good idea, especially if you find more reliable and lightweight [[ranged attack]] options.

The Knight starts with a relatively full set of armor that grants them the best starting [[AC]] of all roles at 3, notably including [[leather gloves]]: while finding lighter and better-quality armor, Knights should seek out a [[cloak]] to protect their body armor from rusting, as well as a set of [[boots]]. Plumbing the [[Gnomish Mines]] for a [[dwarvish mithril-coat]], [[iron shoes]] and/or [[dwarvish iron helm]] is risky - unlit levels rob Knights of most of their mobility and combat advantages; as they are always human and lack [[infravision]], a Knight will want a [[light source]] as soon as possible if they plan to brave the Mines.

Knights looking to start casting early will have to play more carefully than usual: their starting [[intelligence]] is typically low, making it dangerous to read non-blessed [[spellbook]]s, and their metallic armor makes casting itself difficult. Outside of an early wish for [[silver dragon scale mail]], the next best option is [[crystal plate mail]], which is both rare and incredibly heavy - [[studded leather armor]] is the most practical spellcasting-friendly armor, and has the same base AC as [[ring mail]].

===Your steed===
:{{Main|Riding|Saddle}}
For Knights planning to make extensive use of their steed, be sure to bless the [[saddle]] as soon as possible with spare potions of holy water. At minimum, raising the starting pony into a 20-base speed horse is worthwhile, as riding sets the hero's movement speed to that of their mount - remember that all horses are [[vegetarian]], and gain more nutrition from veggy food such as the starting apples and oranges unless they are starving.{{refsrc|src/dogmove.c|142|nethack=3.6.7|name="dog_nutrition"|comment=<tt>dog_nutrition</tt> function - per comment, "It is arbitrary that the pet takes the same length of time to eat as a human, but gets more nutritional value."}}{{refsrc|src/dogmove.c|232|nethack=3.6.7|name="starving_dog"|comment=code in <tt>dog_eat</tt> cuts nutrition gain to {{frac|3|4}} for a starving pet}} A horse close to starvation will also accept "people food" such as [[food ration]]s, or even meat in a pinch - remember to heal them as soon as possible afterward, since starving pets have their maximum HP cut to {{frac|3}} of their normal value.{{refsrc|src/dogmove.c|240|name="notstarving"|comment=feeding starving pets undoes the max HP penalty}}{{refsrc|src/dogmove.c|365|nethack=3.6.7|name="mhpmax_penalty"|comment=<tt>mhpmax_penalty</tt> also cuts current HP if it is above the maximum}}

As a result, while a Knight will not potentially have to compete with their starting pet for food like many other roles, finding suitable food for a pony can be generally more difficult: #[[chat]] to a steed regularly (using {{kbd|>}} if riding it) in order to monitor its status. Carefully rationing the starting food is vital to maintaining the starting steed's health in the long term, and a horse will also gladly feed on the corpses of [[lichen]]s and [[Red mold|red]] or [[brown mold]]s. One good early strategy is to feed the starting pony 9 apples as soon as it drops an item: this increases its tameness enough that a Knight can reliably mount it without slipping - which deals 10-14 damage and [[YASD|may spell doom]] for a starting Knight (sometimes even [[Do not pass go. Do not collect 200 zorkmids.|instantly!]]) - as well as increasing its [[apport]] for liberating items from shops.

Another strategy is to avoid mounting the pony until it has gained enough HP, usually enough to become a horse: by that point, the hero will likely have gained a few levels as well. Steeds in general will not attack monsters as often while the hero is mounted, and will only counterattack if a monster attack targeting you falls upon them instead - it is sometimes best to dismount and let them handle weaker monsters, such as the aforementioned [[Fungus or mold|fungi and molds]]. For a hero short on food in general, one unorthodox method is to leave a level just before the horse becomes confused from hunger, let it go feral, and then return with food after the point where it would have starved if you had remained on the level; taming a monster always sets its hunger level to satiated.

Unknown [[ring]]s present a greater danger than normal for aspiring riders: putting on an unknown [[ring of conflict]] will cause the steed to buck its rider off immediately, resulting in [[wounded legs]] and a possible severe beating before the hero can get their next turn! Additionally, when descending past [[Mine Town]] or below DL 7, be especially careful of [[polymorph traps]]: [[magic resistance]] will protect both the hero and steed from transformation.

===Mid game===
Once decently enchanted, Excalibur is more than sufficient to carry most Knights throughout the entire game. Some Knights may also decide to joust long-term after gaining sufficient skill and [[luck]], obtaining a [[luckstone]] if they haven't already, and may even [[twoweapon]] their lance in the offhand with Excalibur. Improving [[carrying capacity]] is also highly recommended due to the lance's weight. Alignment record is easily recovered by this point, so violations of conduct are often considered an annoyance at worst; taking fewer penalties (or even none) is still ideal, but there is much more room for error.

The stunning from a just can keep monsters off-balance as well, usually knocking them into pounding range; [[invisibility]] or displacement can aid in keeping hostile monsters wandering aimlessly and staying (or straying) into range of further pounds. Even once they have secured enough luck, a Knight will likely want to reserve their lance for stronger opponents in order to further minimize the odds of it breaking, using their primary weapon to handle weaker hostiles. [[Soldier]]s are sometimes generated with lances, making [[barracks]] such as those in [[Fort Ludios]] and the [[Castle]] good places to look for a replacement or spare lance.

Whether or not the hero commits to using a lance or even riding a steed, stashing any treasure and other excess items is an especially good idea for Knights in particular: maximizing speed is extremely important for combat from this point forward, both to keep jumping available as an option and to either evade foes or run them down before they can deal too much damage. A [[bag of holding]] can easily do most of the work in that regard. If you opt to press on while encumbered, be prepared to shed excess items (e.g. stashing them in a [[sack]] that can be dropped at a moment's notice) when dealing with particularly troublesome enemies. The quest nemesis [[Ixoth]] is easily among the tougher hostiles a Knight will face inin general —although he can be dealt with using [[Elbereth]] or paralysis, his [[Monster spell|spellcasting]] ability is annoying to handle without magic resistance, and may warrant heading to the Castle first.

For dedicated Knight riders, [[black dragon]]s are likely the worst threat they can encounter - even if a hero can [[Disintegration resistance|resist]] or [[reflect]] their [[disintegration]] [[breath]] weapons, the vast majority of mounts cannot, and losing a steed to disintegration usually means losing the saddle as well. One of the better tactics to avoid this is to have a means of detecting the dragon beforehand (e.g. via [[Dragonbane]] or [[monster detection]]), use your mount's speed to close in while avoiding their line of fire, and then defeat them in melee by jousting, using Excalibur or any other main weapon of choice. This can also be used to deal with Ixoth by drawing him to your position (typically via the standard cursed [[potion of invisibility]]) and then repeatedly jousting him, which is most effective on a warhorse or faster steed with Expert in lances.

===Late game===
There are many routes for offense that a late game Knight can take, some of which overlap with enough savvy or foresight:

* Excalibur remains a stellar weapon as ever, only potentially being outperformed by [[Frost Brand]] and [[Grayswandir]], and as mentioned earlier can be twoweaponed with weapons such as a lance, a [[silver saber]] or a [[silver spear]]. Knights planning to bribe their way past [[Asmodeus]] and/or [[Baalzebub]] should unwield them before potentially entering their lairs - a demon prince that is generated or warps to demand a bribe while the hero wields Excalibur will immediately turn hostile.
* Knights with Expert in lances and a very fast mount can deal severe damage to monsters such as minotaurs, dragons and high-level demons through jousting and pounding, potentially without losing a single hit point.
* Knights seeking to maintain steeds throughout the entire game will find [[Gehennom]] to be the most difficult challenge in that regard. [[Ki-rin]] are among the most likely to last through Gehennom, and may perhaps be the only ones that can survive the branch consistently: they do not require feeding, have stellar AC, can haste and heal themselves, and Knights will not lower their tameness by mounting one. Unfortunately, they are very hard to obtain, with the best chance being a [[wish]] for a blessed [[figurine]] that has an 80% chance of generating a tamed ki-rin - they are also not immune to [[Wand of death|death]] and disintegration rays, and their lack of poison resistance will likely spell their doom on the [[Plane of Fire]] unless the hero can avoid the [[poison cloud]] plumes.
* Knights that begin investing in spellcasting in the mid-game can amass a formidable array of spells, and their high wisdom naturally lends itself to a large [[energy]] pool. The Magic Mirror allows a knight with a well-trained {{+ of|magic missile}}  However, their energy regeneration is as slow as anyone else's, and one of the best ways to reasonably alleviate this is [[The Mitre of Holiness]], which requires an artifact wish - spellcasting Knights should conserve their spells for the moments when they are most effective. Additionally, the [[Wizard of Yendor]] can steal the Mirror and gain magic resistance, so stashing it may usually be the safer option.

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Ki-rins have poison resistance, and are no longer considered [[animal]]s—they can also cure their status ailments using their horns, similar to [[unicorn]]s and their [[Unicorn horn|horns]].}}

==History==
The Knight first appears in [[Hack 1.0]]

==Origin==
{{Wikipedia|Knight}}
The Knight as a role is based on historical and fictional stereotypes of medieval knights.

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
{{main|Knight/SLASH'EM}}
In [[SLASH'EM]], Knights start out with [[plate mail]] and a [[large shield]] among their armor, which is far heavier but also ensures much better starting AC and carrying capacity; this simplifies the search for better armor such as the various mithril-coats, and can consistently produce a starting strength of at least 18 for valuable early damage bonuses - while their constitution is similarly rarely lower than 12, their HP growth is still somewhat lackluster. Knights retain their starting long sword and ease of access to Excalibur, and the starting steed is also easier to keep fed using the fungi and molds that grow from old corpses.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], a Knight can also be a lawful [[Dwarf (starting race)|dwarf]]. Knights wearing any body armor heavier than [[studded leather armor]] receive a weight reduction for it equal to half the difference;{{refsrc|src/hack.c|3124|unnethack=1465}} this allows them to carry more while wearing heavy armor before becoming burdened.

===FIQHack===
In [[FIQHack]], Knights can be dwarves as well as humans. Knights are always warned before violating their honor code, and [[Dragonbane]] is the guaranteed first sacrifice gift for them.
